This deck covers key C11 (ISO/IEC 9899:2011) features including atomics, generics, multithreading, and memory alignment. text C11 Keyword: _Generic;Purpose: macro overloading based on data type
Syntax:
#define cbrt(X) _Generic((X), \
    long double: cbrtl, \
    default: cbrt, \
    float: cbrtf \
)(X)
C11 Keyword: _Atomic;Purpose: Type specifier/qualifier for thread-safe atomic operations
Example:
_Atomic int counter = 0;
// or
#include <stdatomic.h>
atomic_int counter = 0;
C11 Keyword: _Static_assert;Purpose: Compile-time assertion checking
Syntax:
_Static_assert(sizeof(int) == 4, "Integers must be 32-bit");
C11 Keyword: _Noreturn;Purpose: Function specifier indicating the function never returns (e.g., exit())
Header: <stdnoreturn.h> (macro noreturn) C11 Keyword: _Alignas;Purpose: Specifies the alignment requirement of a variable or member
Example:
_Alignas(16) char buffer[128]; // Align to 16-byte boundary
C11 Keyword: _Alignof;Purpose: Returns the alignment requirement of a type
Example:
size_t alignment = _Alignof(double);
C11 Keyword: _Thread_local;Purpose: Storage class specifier for thread-local storage duration
Header: <threads.h> (macro thread_local) C11 Header: <threads.h>;Purpose: Standard threading support (optional implementation)
Key types/funcs: thrd_t, mtx_t, cnd_t, thrd_create(), thrd_join() C11 Header: <stdatomic.h>;Purpose: Atomic types and operations
Key types/funcs: atomic_store(), atomic_load(), atomic_fetch_add(), atomic_flag C11 Header: <uchar.h>;Purpose: Unicode support
Key types: char16_t (UTF-16), char32_t (UTF-32) C11 Feature: Anonymous Structures/Unions;Description: Allows members of an unnamed struct/union to be accessed as if they were members of the containing struct.
Example:
struct v3 {
  union {
    struct { float x, y, z; };
    float v[3];
  };
};
C11 Feature: fopen() exclusive create;Description: New 'x' mode flag forces fopen to fail if the file already exists.
Example:
FILE *f = fopen("lockfile", "wx");
C11 Feature: quick_exit();Description: Terminates program without executing atexit() handlers, but calls at_quick_exit() handlers.
Purpose: Faster termination for programs that don't need full cleanup. C11 Removal: gets();Description: The dangerous gets() function was permanently removed.
Replacement: fgets() or gets_s() (if Annex K is supported). C11 Feature: Annex K (Bounds-checking);Description: Optional library extensions for safer string/memory handling.
Example: strcpy_s, strcat_s, sprintf_s C11 Feature: CMPLX Macros;Purpose: Macros in <complex.h> to create complex numbers while strictly preserving the imaginary type.
Example: double complex z = CMPLX(0.0, -0.0); gpt-5.2-search Sources preview Below is an Anki/Quizlet-friendly tab-separated (TSV) flashcard deck for C11 (ISO/IEC 9899:2011)ΓÇöone card per line as: Front[TAB]Back C11 adds (among other things) _Atomic/, , _Generic, _Static_assert, _Alignas/_Alignof, _Noreturn, and improved Unicode support (), plus several library additions like aligned_alloc, quick_exit, and timespec_get. 1 Flashcards (TSV import) tsv What does __STDC_VERSION__ typically equal for C11? 201112L (commonly used by compilers to indicate C11 mode). What are the 5 ΓÇ£new headersΓÇ¥ introduced in C11? , , , , . Which C11 keyword enables compile-time type-based selection? _Generic (generic selection expressions). Give the basic syntax of _Generic. _Generic( controlling-expression, type1: expr1, type2: expr2, default: exprD ). In _Generic, what is the controlling expression used for? Only its type is used (to choose an association); it is not evaluated for side effects in the ΓÇ£choose an expression by typeΓÇ¥ sense. In _Generic, can you list two compatible types in the association list? No. ΓÇ£No two type-names ΓÇª may specify compatible types.ΓÇ¥ What C11 feature provides compile-time assertions? _Static_assert (also available as static_assert macro via until C23). Give the C11 syntax for a static assertion. _Static_assert( integer_constant_expression, "message" ); What happens if a _Static_assert condition is false? A compile-time error occurs and the diagnostic should include the message string. What C11 keyword marks a function as not returning? _Noreturn (convenience macro: noreturn in ). What is undefined behavior related to _Noreturn? If a function declared _Noreturn returns normally, behavior is undefined. What header provides the noreturn convenience macro in C11? . Give a correct C11 noreturn function declaration example. 
#include <stdnoreturn.h>
noreturn void die(void) { for(;;) {} }
Which C11 keywords control alignment? _Alignas (set/strengthen alignment) and _Alignof (query alignment). What header provides alignas/alignof convenience macros (pre-C23)? . Give the syntax of _Alignof. _Alignof(type-name) returns alignment requirement as a size_t constant expression. Give the syntax of _Alignas in C11 (two forms). _Alignas(expression) or _Alignas(type). Name the C11 dynamic allocation function for aligned memory. aligned_alloc(alignment, size). What is a key requirement of aligned_allocΓÇÖs size parameter? size must be an integral multiple of alignment. Which C11 keyword introduces atomic types/qualifiers? _Atomic. Give the two C11 forms of _Atomic usage. _Atomic(type-name) (type specifier) and _Atomic type-name (type qualifier). Which header provides the C11 atomic operations library? . What does __STDC_NO_ATOMICS__ indicate? If defined by the compiler, atomic objects/library (including and _Atomic) are not provided. Name the C11 enum that controls atomic memory ordering. enum memory_order. List the C11 memory_order enumerators. memory_order_relaxed, consume, acquire, release, acq_rel, seq_cst. What is the default ordering used by ΓÇ£non-explicitΓÇ¥ atomic operations? Sequentially consistent ordering (memory_order_seq_cst). What does atomic_fetch_add do (high level)? Atomically adds arg to *obj, stores result, returns the old value; it is read-modify-write. Give the signature of atomic_fetch_add_explicit. atomic_fetch_add_explicit(volatile A* obj, M arg, memory_order order). What does atomic_init do, and what is the concurrency caveat? Initializes an atomic object, but the initialization is not atomic; concurrent access during it is a data race. Give a minimal C11 atomic_int initialization example using atomic_init. 
#include <stdatomic.h>
int main(void){ atomic_int x; atomic_init(&x, 0); }
What does atomic_is_lock_free report? Whether a particular atomic object is lock-free on that implementation. Name the C11 lock-free ΓÇ£capability macrosΓÇ¥ pattern. ATOMIC_*_LOCK_FREE (e.g., ATOMIC_INT_LOCK_FREE, ATOMIC_POINTER_LOCK_FREE). What C11 header provides standardized threads? . What does __STDC_NO_THREADS__ indicate? If defined, thread local storage and the thread support library are not supported. What is the return type and function pointer type used by thrd_create? thrd_create takes thrd_start_t, which is typedef int(*)(void*). Give the signature of thrd_create. int thrd_create(thrd_t *thr, thrd_start_t func, void *arg); What does thrd_create guarantee about synchronization? Completion of thrd_create synchronizes-with the beginning of the new thread. How do you declare a thread-local object in C11? Use the storage-class specifier _Thread_local (may combine with static or extern). What is thread_local in C11ΓÇÖs ? A convenience macro: #define thread_local _Thread_local. Give a C11 thread-local variable example. 
#include <threads.h>
thread_local int tls_counter;
What is thrd_join used for? Blocks until a thread terminates (joins with it). What is thrd_detach used for? Detaches a thread (resources released automatically when it ends). Name the C11 mutex type and init function. mtx_t and mtx_init. Name the C11 mutex lock/unlock functions. mtx_lock, mtx_trylock, mtx_timedlock, mtx_unlock. Name the C11 condition variable type and key functions. cnd_t; cnd_init, cnd_wait, cnd_timedwait, cnd_signal, cnd_broadcast, cnd_destroy. What does call_once do in C11 threads? Ensures a function is called exactly once (with once_flag). Name the C11 thread sleep/yield functions. thrd_sleep and thrd_yield. What C11 header adds Unicode conversion utilities? . What are char16_t and char32_t in C11? Unsigned integer types for 16-bit and 32-bit wide characters (typedefs in ). What are the UTF string literal prefixes added/standardized in C11? u8 (UTF-8), u (UTF-16), U (UTF-32). Give an example of a UTF-32 string literal in C11. 
#include <uchar.h>
const char32_t s[] = U"z├ƒµ░┤≡ƒìî";
Which C11 functions convert between multibyte and UTF-16/UTF-32? mbrtoc16/c16rtomb and mbrtoc32/c32rtomb (in ). What C11 program-termination function skips normal cleanup? quick_exit(int exit_code). What functions are called by quick_exit (and in what order)? Functions registered with at_quick_exit, in reverse order; then quick_exit calls _Exit(exit_code). Are atexit handlers called by quick_exit? NoΓÇöquick_exit does not call atexit-registered functions. Give the signature of at_quick_exit. int at_quick_exit(void (*func)(void)); What C11 time structure provides seconds + nanoseconds? struct timespec (in ). What C11 function fills a timespec with current time? int timespec_get(struct timespec *ts, int base); (base often TIME_UTC). What does TIME_UTC mean with timespec_get? It is a macro suitable as the base argument; when base==TIME_UTC, tv_sec/tv_nsec are set to current time (epoch is implementation-defined). What file open mode flag was added/standardized in C11 to prevent overwriting existing files? "x" (append to "w" or "w+" to fail if the file exists). Which unsafe input function was removed in C11? gets(). What does __STDC_LIB_EXT1__ indicate? Bounds-checking interfaces (Annex K / ΓÇ£_sΓÇ¥ functions) are supported by the implementation. How do you request Annex K bounds-checking functions in headers? Define __STDC_WANT_LIB_EXT1__ as 1 before including the relevant header; availability still depends on __STDC_LIB_EXT1__. What C11 function sets the runtime-constraint handler for Annex K calls? set_constraint_handler_s (type constraint_handler_t). Name two standard constraint handlers in C11 Annex K. abort_handler_s and ignore_handler_s. What does __STDC_ANALYZABLE__ indicate? That analyzability support is provided (optional feature). What does __STDC_NO_VLA__ indicate? Variable length arrays (and variably modified types) are not supported (optional in C11). What does __STDC_NO_COMPLEX__ indicate? Complex types and complex math are not supported (optional in C11, though they were mandatory in C99). What C11 language feature allows anonymous struct/union members? Anonymous struct and union members (so members can be accessed as if they were in the containing struct). Give a minimal example of anonymous struct member usage in C11. 
struct S { struct { int x; int y; }; } s; 
/* access: */ s.x = 1;
What is the ΓÇ£exclusive createΓÇ¥ open pattern using C11 fopen? Use mode "wx" (or "w+x") so open fails if the file already exists. Which C11 function allocates aligned memory, and which function frees it? aligned_alloc(...) allocates; free(...) deallocates. In one sentence: what did C11 add for multithreading? A standard memory model with atomics plus a standard threads API () and thread-local storage. What does thrd_current return? The thrd_t identifier of the calling thread.
thrd_t me = thrd_current();
What does thrd_equal do? Compares two thrd_t identifiers. Returns non-zero if they refer to the same thread.
if (thrd_equal(t1, t2)) { ... }
What does thrd_sleep do? Suspends the calling thread for at least the specified duration.
struct timespec ts = {.tv_sec = 1, .tv_nsec = 0};
thrd_sleep(&ts, NULL);
What does thrd_yield do? Yields execution, allowing other threads to run. Advisory only.
thrd_yield();
What does thrd_exit do? Terminates the calling thread with the specified result code.
thrd_exit(0);
What is mtx_t in C11? Mutex type for mutual exclusion.
mtx_t mutex;
What are the mtx_init type flags? 
mtx_plain     // basic mutex
mtx_timed     // supports timed locking
mtx_recursive // can be locked multiple times by same thread
// can combine: mtx_timed | mtx_recursive
What does mtx_lock do? Blocks until the mutex is acquired.
mtx_lock(&mutex);
// critical section
mtx_unlock(&mutex);
What does mtx_trylock do? Attempts to acquire mutex without blocking. Returns thrd_success or thrd_busy.
if (mtx_trylock(&mutex) == thrd_success) { ... }
What does mtx_timedlock do? Attempts to acquire mutex with timeout. Returns thrd_success or thrd_timedout.
struct timespec deadline;
mtx_timedlock(&mutex, &deadline);
What is cnd_t in C11? Condition variable type for thread synchronization.
cnd_t cond;
What does cnd_wait do? Atomically unlocks the mutex and blocks until signaled, then re-locks.
mtx_lock(&mutex);
while (!condition)
    cnd_wait(&cond, &mutex);
mtx_unlock(&mutex);
What does cnd_signal do? Unblocks at least one thread waiting on the condition variable.
cnd_signal(&cond);
What does cnd_broadcast do? Unblocks all threads waiting on the condition variable.
cnd_broadcast(&cond);
What is once_flag and call_once for? One-time initialization. The function is called exactly once regardless of how many threads call call_once.
once_flag flag = ONCE_FLAG_INIT;
call_once(&flag, init_function);
What is tss_t in C11? Thread-specific storage key type. Each thread can store a unique value associated with the key.
tss_t key;
tss_create(&key, destructor_func);
What are the C11 thread function return codes? 
thrd_success  // operation succeeded
thrd_nomem    // memory allocation failed
thrd_timedout // timed operation timed out
thrd_busy     // resource busy (trylock failed)
thrd_error    // other error occurred
# === SECTION 6: Unicode Support === What is char16_t in C11? An unsigned integer type for 16-bit characters (UTF-16 code units). Defined in <uchar.h>.
char16_t ch = u'A';
What is char32_t in C11? An unsigned integer type for 32-bit characters (UTF-32 code points). Defined in <uchar.h>.
char32_t ch = U'\U0001F600';
What does the u8 string literal prefix produce? A UTF-8 encoded string (char array).
const char *s = u8"Hello";
What does the u string literal prefix produce? A UTF-16 encoded string (char16_t array).
const char16_t *s = u"Hello";
What does the U string literal prefix produce? A UTF-32 encoded string (char32_t array).
const char32_t *s = U"Hello \U0001F600";
What does mbrtoc16 do? Converts a multibyte character to UTF-16. May produce one or two char16_t (surrogate pair).
size_t mbrtoc16(char16_t *pc16, const char *s,
                size_t n, mbstate_t *ps);
What does c16rtomb do? Converts a UTF-16 character to multibyte.
size_t c16rtomb(char *s, char16_t c16,
                mbstate_t *ps);
What does mbrtoc32 do? Converts a multibyte character to UTF-32.
size_t mbrtoc32(char32_t *pc32, const char *s,
                size_t n, mbstate_t *ps);
# === SECTION 7: Library Additions === What is aligned_alloc in C11? Allocates memory with specified alignment.
void *aligned_alloc(size_t alignment, size_t size);

size must be a multiple of alignment. Free with free(). What is the key constraint on aligned_alloc? The size must be an integral multiple of alignment. Otherwise behavior is undefined. What is quick_exit in C11? Fast program termination. Calls at_quick_exit handlers then _Exit. Does NOT call atexit handlers.
quick_exit(EXIT_SUCCESS);
What is at_quick_exit in C11? Registers a function to be called by quick_exit (in reverse order of registration).
at_quick_exit(cleanup_func);
What is the difference between quick_exit and exit? exit: Calls atexit handlers, flushes streams, closes files.
quick_exit: Only calls at_quick_exit handlers, then _Exit (no cleanup). What is struct timespec in C11? A structure for time with nanosecond precision.
struct timespec {
    time_t tv_sec;  // seconds
    long tv_nsec;   // nanoseconds [0, 999999999]
};
What is timespec_get in C11? Fills a timespec with the current time.
struct timespec ts;
timespec_get(&ts, TIME_UTC);
What is TIME_UTC in C11? A macro used with timespec_get to request calendar time in UTC. The epoch is implementation-defined. What does the "x" fopen mode do in C11? Exclusive create. Fails if the file already exists. Prevents accidental overwriting.
FILE *f = fopen("lockfile", "wx");
if (!f) { /* file exists or error */ }
Why was gets removed in C11? Buffer overflow vulnerability. gets() had no way to limit input length. Replaced by fgets() or gets_s(). What replaces gets() in C11? fgets() (standard) or gets_s() (Annex K).
char buf[100];
fgets(buf, sizeof buf, stdin);
# === SECTION 8: Annex K Bounds-Checking === What is __STDC_WANT_LIB_EXT1__ for? Request Annex K functions. Define as 1 before including headers to get _s function declarations.
#define __STDC_WANT_LIB_EXT1__ 1
#include <string.h>
What is constraint_handler_t? The type of Annex K error handlers.
typedef void (*constraint_handler_t)(
    const char *msg,
    void *ptr,
    errno_t error
);
What does set_constraint_handler_s do? Sets the runtime-constraint handler for Annex K functions. Returns the previous handler.
set_constraint_handler_s(my_handler);
What is abort_handler_s? The default Annex K handler. Writes a message to stderr and calls abort(). What is ignore_handler_s? An Annex K handler that does nothing. Functions return error codes but don't abort. What is strcpy_s? Bounds-checked string copy.
errno_t strcpy_s(char *dest, rsize_t destsz,
                 const char *src);
What is sprintf_s? Bounds-checked sprintf.
int sprintf_s(char *s, rsize_t n,
              const char *format, ...);
What is rsize_t in Annex K? A size_t-like type with a maximum value (RSIZE_MAX). Values exceeding RSIZE_MAX trigger constraint handlers. What is RSIZE_MAX? The maximum valid value for rsize_t parameters. Typically SIZE_MAX >> 1. Prevents suspiciously large size values. # === SECTION 9: Language Features === What are anonymous structs/unions in C11? Unnamed struct/union members whose fields are accessed as if they belong to the enclosing struct.
struct vec3 {
    union {
        struct { float x, y, z; };
        float v[3];
    };
};
vec3 v; v.x = 1.0f; // direct access
What is the benefit of anonymous structs/unions? Cleaner syntax. No need to name intermediate containers. Common in hardware registers and variant types. What are CMPLX, CMPLXF, CMPLXL macros? Complex number construction in <complex.h>. Properly preserve signed zeros.
double complex z = CMPLX(0.0, -0.0);
Why use CMPLX instead of arithmetic construction? Preserves signed zeros. (0.0 + -0.0*I) may not preserve -0.0 in the imaginary part due to arithmetic rules. Are VLAs mandatory in C11? No. Variable Length Arrays became optional. Check __STDC_NO_VLA__ for availability. What changed about complex numbers in C11? They became optional. Check __STDC_NO_COMPLEX__. They were mandatory in C99. "}

# C90 (ISO/IEC 9899:1990) vs C89 Flashcard Deck # Import: Anki > File > Import, select TSV, Fields separated by Tab # Enable "Allow HTML in fields" # C90 is essentially identical to C89 - this covers the relationship and minor differences # === SECTION 1: Relationship Between C89 and C90 === What is C89? ANSI X3.159-1989 - The first standardized version of C, published by ANSI (American National Standards Institute) in 1989. What is C90? ISO/IEC 9899:1990 - The international adoption of C89 by ISO. Technically identical to C89 with formatting differences. Are C89 and C90 the same language? Yes. C90 adopted C89 unchanged. The terms are often used interchangeably. Differences are purely editorial/formatting. Why do both "C89" and "C90" names exist? C89: Named for ANSI publication year (1989)
C90: Named for ISO publication year (1990)
They refer to the same language specification. What is "ANSI C"? A common name for C89/C90. Technically ambiguous since later standards are also ANSI standards, but historically refers to the 1989 standard. What is "ISO C"? Can refer to any ISO C standard (C90, C99, C11, C17, C23). Context determines which version. # === SECTION 2: Technical Content (Identical in Both) === How many keywords in C89/C90? 32 keywords. Same in both standards. How many standard headers in C89/C90? 15 headers. Same in both standards:
<assert.h> <ctype.h> <errno.h> <float.h> <limits.h> <locale.h> <math.h> <setjmp.h> <signal.h> <stdarg.h> <stddef.h> <stdio.h> <stdlib.h> <string.h> <time.h> Are trigraphs in C89 or C90? Both. Trigraphs were defined in C89 (ANSI) and carried into C90 unchanged.
??=  #     ??/  \
??(  [     ??)  ]
??<  {     ??>  }
??'  ^     ??!  |
??-  ~
What is __STDC__ in C89/C90? Predefined macro set to 1 if the implementation conforms to the standard.
#if __STDC__
    // standard C
#endif
# === SECTION 3: Editorial Differences === What formatting differences exist between C89 and C90? Section numbering differs between ANSI and ISO formats.
Foreword/Introduction text differs.
Normative references formatted per ISO style.
No language or library changes. Did C90 add any new features to C89? No. C90 is a reformatted adoption of C89 with no technical changes. Did C90 add __STDC_VERSION__? No. __STDC_VERSION__ was added in the 1994 amendment (C95 / Amendment 1). C89/C90 only have __STDC__. # === SECTION 4: Amendment 1 (C95) === What is C95 / Amendment 1? ISO/IEC 9899/AMD1:1995 - An amendment to C90 adding wide character and digraph support. Sometimes called "C94" or "C95". What did C95 add to C90? New headers: <iso646.h>, <wchar.h>, <wctype.h>
Digraphs (alternative tokens)
__STDC_VERSION__ macro
Wide string/character functions What value is __STDC_VERSION__ for C95? 199409L (September 1994).
#if __STDC_VERSION__ >= 199409L
    // C95 or later
#endif
What are the C95 digraphs? Alternative spellings for tokens:
<:  [      :>  ]
<%  {      %>  }
%:  #      %:%: ##

Easier to type on some keyboards than trigraphs. What does <iso646.h> provide (C95)? Alternative spellings as macros:
and    &&      or     ||
not    !       xor    ^
and_eq &=      or_eq  |=
not_eq !=      xor_eq ^=
bitand &       bitor  |
compl  ~
What does <wchar.h> provide (C95)? Wide character I/O and string functions:
wchar_t, wint_t, WEOF
fwprintf, fwscanf, wprintf, wscanf
fgetwc, fputwc, fgetws, fputws
wcscpy, wcscat, wcslen, wcscmp
mbrtowc, wcrtomb, mbsrtowcs
What does <wctype.h> provide (C95)? Wide character classification:
iswalpha, iswdigit, iswalnum
iswspace, iswupper, iswlower
towupper, towlower
wctype, iswctype
# === SECTION 5: Technical Corrigenda === What are Technical Corrigenda? Bug fixes to the standard. C90 had two (TC1 1994, TC2 1996) fixing ambiguities and errors. No new features added. What is a Normative Addendum vs Corrigendum? Addendum/Amendment: Adds new features (e.g., C95 adds digraphs)
Corrigendum: Fixes errors without adding features # === SECTION 6: Choosing Standard Versions === How do you request C90 mode in GCC? 
gcc -std=c90 program.c
gcc -std=iso9899:1990 program.c
gcc -ansi program.c
How do you request C90 mode in Clang? 
clang -std=c90 program.c
clang -std=c89 program.c
How do you request C95 mode in GCC? 
gcc -std=iso9899:199409 program.c
Should new code target C89/C90? Generally no. Modern code should use C11 or C17 for better features and safety. Target C89/C90 only for extreme portability to legacy systems.

data.text:
Created `c11-flashcards.tsv` with **86 flashcards** covering all C11 (ISO/IEC 9899:2011) additions versus C99.

**File summary:**

| Section | Cards | Topics |
|---------|-------|--------|
| Feature Test Macros | 7 | `__STDC_VERSION__`, `__STDC_NO_*` macros |
| New Keywords | 12 | `_Generic`, `_Atomic`, `_Static_assert`, `_Noreturn`, `_Alignas`, `_Alignof`, `_Thread_local` |
| New Headers | 6 | `<stdatomic.h>`, `<stdalign.h>`, `<stdnoreturn.h>`, `<threads.h>`, `<uchar.h>` |
| Atomics Deep Dive | 16 | `memory_order`, atomic operations, `atomic_flag`, lock-free macros |
| Threading | 21 | `thrd_*`, `mtx_*`, `cnd_*`, `tss_*`, `call_once`, return codes |
| Unicode Support | 8 | `char16_t`, `char32_t`, UTF literals, conversion functions |
| Library Additions | 12 | `aligned_alloc`, `quick_exit`, `timespec_get`, `fopen` "x" mode, `gets` removal |
| Annex K Bounds-Checking | 9 | `*_s` functions, constraint handlers, `rsize_t` |
| Language Features | 6 | Anonymous structs/unions, `CMPLX` macros, VLA optionality |

**Import instructions:**
1. Open Anki > File > Import
2. Select `c11-flashcards.tsv`
3. Set "Fields separated by: Tab"
4. Enable "Allow HTML in fields"
5. Lines starting with `#` are comments and will be skipped

{"diff":{"chunks":[{"diffString":"- + # C89 (ANSI C / X3.159-1989) Flashcard Deck + # Import: Anki > File > Import, select TSV, Fields separated by Tab + # Enable "Allow HTML in fields" + # The foundational C standard - covers complete language specification + + # === SECTION 1: Keywords (32 total) === + List all 32 C89 keywords. 
auto     break    case     char
+ const    continue default  do
+ double   else     enum     extern
+ float    for      goto     if
+ int      long     register return
+ short    signed   sizeof   static
+ struct   switch   typedef  union
+ unsigned void     volatile while
+ What does the auto keyword do in C89? Storage class specifier for automatic (local) storage duration. Default for local variables, rarely written explicitly.
auto int x = 5; // same as: int x = 5;
+ What does the register keyword do in C89? Hint to compiler to store variable in a CPU register for fast access. Cannot take address of register variables.
register int i;
+ for (i = 0; i < 1000; i++) { ... }
+ What does the static keyword do in C89? Two uses:
1. Local variable: persists across function calls
2. File scope: limits visibility to current translation unit
static int counter = 0;  // persistent local
+ static void helper(void); // internal linkage
+ What does the extern keyword do in C89? Declares a variable or function defined elsewhere (external linkage).
extern int global_count;  // defined in another file
+ extern void func(void);   // optional for functions
+ What does the const keyword do in C89? Type qualifier indicating the value cannot be modified after initialization.
const int MAX = 100;
+ const char *str = "hello"; // pointer to const char
+ What does the volatile keyword do in C89? Type qualifier telling compiler the value may change unexpectedly (hardware registers, signal handlers). Prevents optimization.
volatile int *port = (int *)0x40000000;
+ What does typedef do in C89? Creates an alias for a type. Does not create a new type.
typedef unsigned long size_t;
+ typedef struct node Node;
+ What does sizeof do in C89? Operator returning the size in bytes of a type or expression (as size_t).
sizeof(int)       // size of int
+ sizeof(array)     // total array size
+ sizeof array[0]   // size of one element
+ + # === SECTION 2: Data Types === + What are the basic integer types in C89? 
char              // at least 8 bits
+ short [int]       // at least 16 bits
+ int               // at least 16 bits
+ long [int]        // at least 32 bits

Each can be signed or unsigned. + What are the floating-point types in C89? 
float       // single precision
+ double      // double precision
+ long double // extended precision
+ What is the void type in C89? Incomplete type with no values.
Uses:
- Function returning nothing: void func(void)
- Generic pointer: void *ptr
- Discard expression: (void)unused_result; + What does signed vs unsigned mean? signed: Can represent negative values (two's complement typical)
unsigned: Only non-negative values, larger positive range
signed char:   -128 to 127
+ unsigned char: 0 to 255
+ What is the minimum range of int in C89? -32767 to +32767 (at least 16 bits). Defined in <limits.h> as INT_MIN and INT_MAX. + What is the minimum range of long in C89? -2147483647 to +2147483647 (at least 32 bits). Defined in <limits.h> as LONG_MIN and LONG_MAX. + What is the char type in C89? Smallest addressable unit. May be signed or unsigned (implementation-defined). Always exactly 1 byte by definition. + What header defines integer limits in C89? <limits.h>
CHAR_BIT   // bits in char (at least 8)
+ CHAR_MIN, CHAR_MAX
+ INT_MIN, INT_MAX
+ LONG_MIN, LONG_MAX
+ UCHAR_MAX, UINT_MAX, ULONG_MAX
+ What header defines floating-point limits in C89? <float.h>
FLT_MIN, FLT_MAX, FLT_EPSILON
+ DBL_MIN, DBL_MAX, DBL_EPSILON
+ LDBL_MIN, LDBL_MAX
+ + # === SECTION 3: Operators === + List the arithmetic operators in C89. 
+   // addition, unary plus
+ -   // subtraction, unary minus
+ *   // multiplication
+ /   // division
+ %   // modulo (integers only)
+ List the relational operators in C89. 
<   // less than
+ >   // greater than
+ <=  // less than or equal
+ >=  // greater than or equal
+ ==  // equal
+ !=  // not equal

Result is int: 0 (false) or 1 (true). + List the logical operators in C89. 
&&  // logical AND (short-circuit)
+ ||  // logical OR (short-circuit)
+ !   // logical NOT

Operands treated as boolean (0 = false, non-zero = true). + List the bitwise operators in C89. 
&   // bitwise AND
+ |   // bitwise OR
+ ^   // bitwise XOR
+ ~   // bitwise NOT (ones complement)
+ <<  // left shift
+ >>  // right shift
+ List the assignment operators in C89. 
=   // simple assignment
+ +=  -= *= /= %=   // compound arithmetic
+ &=  |= ^=         // compound bitwise
+ <<= >>=           // compound shift
+ What are the increment/decrement operators? 
++x  // pre-increment: increment, return new value
+ x++  // post-increment: return old value, increment
+ --x  // pre-decrement
+ x--  // post-decrement
+ What is the conditional (ternary) operator? 
condition ? expr1 : expr2

If condition is true, evaluates and returns expr1; otherwise expr2. + What is the comma operator? Evaluates left operand, discards result, evaluates and returns right operand.
x = (a++, b++, c);  // x = c
+ What is the sizeof operator? Returns size in bytes as size_t. Can take type or expression.
sizeof(int)
+ sizeof x
+ sizeof(struct foo)
+ What are the pointer operators in C89? 
&   // address-of: get pointer to object
+ *   // dereference: access pointed-to object
+ ->  // member access through pointer
+ []  // array subscript (pointer + offset)
+ What is C89 operator precedence (highest to lowest)? 
() [] -> .              // postfix

What does the auto keyword do in C89? Storage class specifier for automatic (local) storage duration. Default for local variables, rarely written explicitly.
auto int x = 5; // same as: int x = 5;
What does the register keyword do in C89? Hint to compiler to store variable in a CPU register for fast access. Cannot take address of register variables.
register int i;
for (i = 0; i < 1000; i++) { ... }
What does the static keyword do in C89? Two uses:
1. Local variable: persists across function calls
2. File scope: limits visibility to current translation unit
static int counter = 0;  // persistent local
static void helper(void); // internal linkage
What does the extern keyword do in C89? Declares a variable or function defined elsewhere (external linkage).
extern int global_count;  // defined in another file
extern void func(void);   // optional for functions
What does the const keyword do in C89? Type qualifier indicating the value cannot be modified after initialization.
const int MAX = 100;
const char *str = "hello"; // pointer to const char
What does the volatile keyword do in C89? Type qualifier telling compiler the value may change unexpectedly (hardware registers, signal handlers). Prevents optimization.
volatile int *port = (int *)0x40000000;
What does typedef do in C89? Creates an alias for a type. Does not create a new type.
typedef unsigned long size_t;
typedef struct node Node;
What does sizeof do in C89? Operator returning the size in bytes of a type or expression (as size_t).
sizeof(int)       // size of int
sizeof(array)     // total array size
sizeof array[0]   // size of one element

unsigned: Only non-negative values, larger positive range
signed char:   -128 to 127
unsigned char: 0 to 255
What is the minimum range of int in C89? -32767 to +32767 (at least 16 bits). Defined in <limits.h> as INT_MIN and INT_MAX. What is the minimum range of long in C89? -2147483647 to +2147483647 (at least 32 bits). Defined in <limits.h> as LONG_MIN and LONG_MAX. What is the char type in C89? Smallest addressable unit. May be signed or unsigned (implementation-defined). Always exactly 1 byte by definition. What header defines integer limits in C89? <limits.h>

What is the NULL pointer? A pointer value indicating no valid address. Defined in <stddef.h>, <stdlib.h>, etc.
int *p = NULL;
if (p != NULL) { ... }
What is pointer arithmetic? Adding/subtracting integers to/from pointers. Moves by element size.
int arr[5];
int *p = arr;
p++;        // moves sizeof(int) bytes
p += 2;     // moves 2*sizeof(int) bytes
What is the relationship between arrays and pointers? Array name decays to pointer to first element in most contexts.
int arr[5];
int *p = arr;     // p = &arr[0]
arr[i] == *(p+i)  // equivalent access
What is a pointer to pointer? A pointer that holds the address of another pointer.
int x = 10;
int *p = &x;
int **pp = &p;
**pp = 20;  // x is now 20
What is a function pointer? A pointer to a function's code.
int (*fp)(int, int);  // pointer to int(int,int)
fp = add;
int result = fp(3, 4);
What is a void pointer? A generic pointer that can point to any type. Cannot be dereferenced without casting.
void *p = malloc(100);
int *ip = (int *)p;
# === SECTION 7: Arrays === How do you declare an array in C89? 
int arr[10];           // 10 ints
char str[100];         // 100 chars
double matrix[3][4];   // 3x4 matrix

Size must be a constant expression. How do you initialize an array in C89? 
int arr[5] = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
int arr[] = {1, 2, 3};  // size inferred (3)
int arr[5] = {1, 2};    // rest are 0
int arr[5] = {0};       // all zeros
What is array-to-pointer decay? Arrays automatically convert to pointers to their first element, except with sizeof or &.
int arr[5];
int *p = arr;        // decay: p = &arr[0]
sizeof(arr);         // no decay: returns 20
&arr;                // no decay: int(*)[5]
What is a multidimensional array? An array of arrays. Stored in row-major order.
int matrix[3][4];      // 3 rows, 4 columns
matrix[1][2] = 5;      // row 1, column 2
// equivalent: *(*(matrix+1)+2) = 5
How do you pass an array to a function? Arrays decay to pointers. Size is lost.
void f(int arr[], int size);  // equivalent to:
void f(int *arr, int size);

// For 2D arrays, specify all but first dimension:
void g(int arr[][4], int rows);
# === SECTION 8: Structures and Unions === What is a struct in C89? A composite type grouping related variables.
struct point {
    int x;
    int y;
};
struct point p = {10, 20};
p.x = 30;
What is a union in C89? A type where all members share the same memory. Only one member is valid at a time.
union value {
    int i;
    float f;
    char c;
};
sizeof(union value) == sizeof(largest member)
How do you access struct members? 
struct point p;
p.x = 10;       // direct access with .

struct point *pp = &p;
pp->x = 20;     // pointer access with ->
(*pp).x = 20;   // equivalent
What is struct padding? Compilers add padding bytes for alignment. Members may not be contiguous.
struct s {
    char c;     // 1 byte + 3 padding
    int i;      // 4 bytes
};  // sizeof = 8, not 5
What is a bit-field in C89? Struct members with specified bit widths.
struct flags {
    unsigned int ready : 1;
    unsigned int error : 1;
    unsigned int count : 6;
};
Can you have a pointer to a struct inside the struct? Yes. Self-referential structures enable linked data structures.
struct node {
    int data;
    struct node *next;
};
# === SECTION 9: Enumerations === What is an enum in C89? A set of named integer constants.
enum color { RED, GREEN, BLUE };
// RED=0, GREEN=1, BLUE=2

enum color c = GREEN;
How do you specify enum values? 
enum status {
    OK = 0,
    ERROR = -1,
    PENDING = 100,
    DONE       // 101 (continues from previous)
};
What type is an enum value? int. Enums are compatible with int and can be used interchangeably. # === SECTION 10: Preprocessor === What are the preprocessor directives in C89? 
#include   // include file
#define    // define macro
#undef     // undefine macro
#if #ifdef #ifndef #elif #else #endif // conditional
#line      // set line number
#error     // generate error
#pragma    // implementation-defined
How does #include work? 
#include <stdio.h>   // search system paths
#include "myfile.h"  // search current dir first

Textually inserts the file contents. How does #define work for constants? 
#define MAX 100
#define PI 3.14159
#define MSG "Hello"

Simple text substitution. How does #define work for macros? 
#define MAX(a,b) ((a) > (b) ? (a) : (b))
#define SQUARE(x) ((x) * (x))

Parenthesize everything to avoid precedence bugs. What is the # (stringizing) operator? Converts macro argument to string literal.
#define STR(x) #x
STR(hello)  // "hello"
What is the ## (token pasting) operator? Concatenates two tokens.
#define CONCAT(a,b) a##b
CONCAT(foo,bar)  // foobar
What are the predefined macros in C89? 
__LINE__  // current line number
__FILE__  // current filename
__DATE__  // compilation date "Mmm dd yyyy"
__TIME__  // compilation time "hh:mm:ss"
__STDC__  // 1 if conforming implementation
What does #ifdef do? Conditional compilation. Block included if macro is defined.
#ifdef DEBUG
    printf("debug: x=%d\n", x);
#endif
What does #ifndef do? Conditional compilation. Block included if macro is NOT defined. Common for include guards.
#ifndef HEADER_H
#define HEADER_H
// header contents
#endif
# === SECTION 11: Standard Library Headers === List the C89 standard library headers. 
<assert.h>  <ctype.h>   <errno.h>
<float.h>   <limits.h>  <locale.h>
<math.h>    <setjmp.h>  <signal.h>
<stdarg.h>  <stddef.h>  <stdio.h>
<stdlib.h>  <string.h>  <time.h>

15 standard headers. What does <stdio.h> provide? Input/Output:
FILE, stdin, stdout, stderr
printf, scanf, fprintf, fscanf
fopen, fclose, fread, fwrite
fgets, fputs, getc, putc
fseek, ftell, rewind
What does <stdlib.h> provide? General utilities:
malloc, calloc, realloc, free
atoi, atof, atol, strtol, strtod
rand, srand
qsort, bsearch
exit, abort, atexit
abs, labs, div, ldiv
What does <string.h> provide? String/memory functions:
strlen, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat
strcmp, strncmp, strchr, strrchr, strstr
memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, memchr
What does <math.h> provide? Math functions:
sin, cos, tan, asin, acos, atan, atan2
sinh, cosh, tanh
exp, log, log10, pow, sqrt
ceil, floor, fabs, fmod
What does <ctype.h> provide? Character classification:
isalpha, isdigit, isalnum, isspace
isupper, islower, isprint, ispunct
toupper, tolower
What does <assert.h> provide? assert macro for runtime checks. If expression is false, prints message and aborts.
assert(ptr != NULL);
// disabled if NDEBUG defined
What does <errno.h> provide? errno macro and error codes.
errno = 0;
result = sqrt(-1);
if (errno == EDOM) { ... }
What does <setjmp.h> provide? Non-local jumps for error handling.
jmp_buf env;
if (setjmp(env) == 0) {
    // normal execution
} else {
    // returned from longjmp
}
longjmp(env, 1);  // jump back
What does <signal.h> provide? Signal handling:
signal(SIGINT, handler);
raise(SIGTERM);

Standard signals: SIGABRT, SIGFPE, SIGILL, SIGINT, SIGSEGV, SIGTERM What does <time.h> provide? Date and time:
time_t, struct tm, clock_t
time, difftime, mktime
gmtime, localtime, strftime
clock
What does <stddef.h> provide? Common definitions:
NULL      // null pointer constant
size_t    // unsigned size type
ptrdiff_t // signed pointer difference type
offsetof  // byte offset of struct member
# === SECTION 12: Memory Management === What does malloc do? Allocates uninitialized memory. Returns NULL on failure.
int *p = malloc(10 * sizeof(int));
if (p == NULL) { /* error */ }
What does calloc do? Allocates and zero-initializes memory.
int *p = calloc(10, sizeof(int));
// all 10 ints are initialized to 0
What does realloc do? Resizes previously allocated memory. May move the block.
p = realloc(p, 20 * sizeof(int));
// preserve original if realloc fails:
int *tmp = realloc(p, newsize);
if (tmp) p = tmp;
What does free do? Deallocates memory from malloc/calloc/realloc. Passing NULL is safe (no-op).
free(p);
p = NULL;  // good practice
What is a memory leak? Allocated memory that is no longer reachable and cannot be freed. Wastes memory over time. What is a dangling pointer? A pointer to memory that has been freed or is out of scope. Dereferencing is undefined behavior. What is a double free? Calling free() on the same pointer twice. Undefined behavior, often causes crashes or security vulnerabilities. # === SECTION 13: I/O Details === What is the difference between text and binary mode? Text mode: Newline translation (\\n to platform-specific). Character-oriented.
Binary mode: No translation. Byte-for-byte exact. What are the fopen mode strings? 
"r"  // read text
"w"  // write text (truncate/create)
"a"  // append text
"r+" // read+write text
"w+" // read+write (truncate/create)
"a+" // read+append
"rb" "wb" "ab" // binary modes
What does printf return? The number of characters printed, or negative on error.
int n = printf("Hello");  // n = 5
What are the printf format specifiers? 
%d %i  // int (decimal)
%u     // unsigned int
%x %X  // unsigned hex
%o     // unsigned octal
%f %F  // double
%e %E  // scientific notation
%g %G  // shortest of %f or %e
%c     // char
%s     // string
%p     // pointer
%%     // literal %
What does scanf return? The number of items successfully converted, or EOF on error/end.
int n;
if (scanf("%d", &n) != 1) { /* error */ }
What is the difference between getc and fgetc? getc: May be implemented as macro (evaluates stream multiple times).
fgetc: Always a function. Safer but possibly slower. What does feof do? Returns non-zero if end-of-file indicator is set. Check AFTER a read fails, not before.
while (fgets(buf, sizeof buf, fp)) { ... }
if (feof(fp)) { /* normal end */ }
What does ferror do? Returns non-zero if error indicator is set for the stream.
if (ferror(fp)) { /* I/O error occurred */ }
# === SECTION 14: String Handling === What does strcpy do and why is it dangerous? Copies string including null terminator. Dangerous: No bounds checking, can overflow destination.
char dest[10];
strcpy(dest, source);  // buffer overflow if source > 9 chars
What does strncpy do? Copies at most n characters. Warning: May NOT null-terminate if source is too long.
strncpy(dest, source, sizeof(dest) - 1);
dest[sizeof(dest) - 1] = '\0';  // ensure termination
What does strcmp return? 0 if equal, <0 if s1 < s2, >0 if s1 > s2.
if (strcmp(s1, s2) == 0) { /* equal */ }
What does strlen return? Length of string (not including null terminator).
size_t len = strlen("hello");  // 5
What does strchr do? Returns pointer to first occurrence of character, or NULL if not found.
char *p = strchr(str, 'x');
What does strstr do? Returns pointer to first occurrence of substring, or NULL if not found.
char *p = strstr(haystack, "needle");
What does strtok do? Tokenizes a string. Modifies the original string. Uses static state (not thread-safe).
char *tok = strtok(str, " ,");
while (tok) {
    // process tok
    tok = strtok(NULL, " ,");
}
# === SECTION 15: Type Conversions === What are the integer promotions? Values narrower than int are promoted to int (or unsigned int) in expressions.
char, short, bit-fields all promote to int before arithmetic. What is the usual arithmetic conversion? When operands have different types, they are converted to a common type:
1. If either is long double, convert both
2. Else if either is double, convert both
3. Else if either is float, convert both
4. Else apply integer promotions, then convert to wider/unsigned as needed What is implicit conversion? Automatic type conversion by compiler. May lose precision.
int i = 3.7;     // i = 3 (truncation)
float f = 10/3;  // f = 3.0 (integer division)
What is explicit conversion (casting)? Programmer-specified type conversion using cast operator.
double d = (double)10 / 3;  // 3.333...
int *p = (int *)malloc(40);
# === SECTION 16: Undefined Behavior Examples === What is undefined behavior (UB)? Code for which the C standard imposes no requirements. Anything can happen: crash, wrong result, appear to work. List common causes of undefined behavior. 
- Null pointer dereference
- Buffer overflow
- Signed integer overflow
- Use after free
- Double free
- Uninitialized variable use
- Division by zero
- Invalid pointer arithmetic
- Modifying string literals
Why is signed integer overflow undefined? Allows compilers to optimize assuming it never happens. Two's complement wraparound is NOT guaranteed.
int x = INT_MAX;
x + 1;  // UB, not guaranteed to wrap
"}

thinking.text:
Now creating the C90 deck. C90 (ISO/IEC 9899:1990) is essentially identical to C89 (ANSI X3.159-1989), with only minor editorial differences. The main points:

1. Same language and library
2. Trigraphs were already in C89, but some consider them "formalized" in ISO
3. Minor wording clarifications
4. __STDC_VERSION__ was not added until the 1994 amendment (C95)
5. The digraphs came in C95 (Technical Corrigendum 1 / Amendment 1)

So C90 deck will be small - mainly explaining the relationship and the few nuances.

  - New keywords: _Generic, _Atomic, _Static_assert, _Noreturn, _Alignas, _Alignof, _Thread_local

  - Threading: thrd_t, mtx_t, cnd_t, thrd_create, thrd_join, etc.

  - Unicode: char16_t, char32_t, u8/u/U literals
  - Library additions: aligned_alloc, quick_exit, at_quick_exit, timespec_get
  - Annex K: bounds-checking interfaces
  - Feature test macros: __STDC_VERSION__, __STDC_NO_ATOMICS__, etc.
  - Removed features: gets()
  - Anonymous structs/unions
  - Exclusive file open mode ("x")

{"diff":{"chunks":[{"diffString":"- + # C99 (ISO/IEC 9899:1999) Flashcard Deck + # Import: Anki > File > Import, select TSV, Fields separated by Tab + # Enable "Allow HTML in fields" + # Covers all C99 additions compared to C90/C95 + + # === SECTION 1: Overview and Version Detection === + What is C99? ISO/IEC 9899:1999 - Major revision of C adding many features: VLAs, inline, restrict, long long, designated initializers, // comments, and more. + What value is __STDC_VERSION__ for C99? 199901L
#if __STDC_VERSION__ >= 199901L
+     // C99 or later
+ #endif
+ How many new keywords did C99 add? 5 keywords: inline, restrict, _Bool, _Complex, _Imaginary + How many new headers did C99 add? 6 headers: <stdbool.h>, <stdint.h>, <inttypes.h>, <complex.h>, <tgmath.h>, <fenv.h> + How do you request C99 mode in GCC/Clang? 
gcc -std=c99 program.c
+ clang -std=c99 program.c
+ + # === SECTION 2: New Keywords === + What does the inline keyword do in C99? Hints to compiler that function calls should be expanded inline. Does not guarantee inlining.
inline int square(int x) {
+     return x * x;
+ }
+ What are the inline semantics in C99? inline alone provides no external definition (for headers).
extern inline provides external definition.
// header: inline int f(int x) { return x*2; }
+ // one .c file: extern inline int f(int x);
+ What does the restrict keyword do in C99? Pointer qualifier promising no aliasing. Enables better optimization.
void copy(int *restrict dest,
+           const int *restrict src, size_t n);
+ When should you use restrict? When pointers don't alias (point to overlapping memory). If they do alias and you use restrict, behavior is undefined. + What is _Bool in C99? Boolean type that can hold 0 or 1. Any non-zero value converted to _Bool becomes 1.
_Bool flag = 42;  // flag = 1
+ What is _Complex in C99? Complex number types:
float _Complex
+ double _Complex
+ long double _Complex

Requires <complex.h> for operations. + What is _Imaginary in C99? Imaginary-only types. Optional feature, rarely supported.
float _Imaginary
+ double _Imaginary

Check __STDC_IEC_559_COMPLEX__ for support. + + # === SECTION 3: New Headers === + What does <stdbool.h> provide? Boolean macros:
bool   // macro for _Bool
+ true   // macro for 1
+ false  // macro for 0
+ __bool_true_false_are_defined // 1
+ What does <stdint.h> provide? Fixed-width integer types:
int8_t, int16_t, int32_t, int64_t
+ uint8_t, uint16_t, uint32_t, uint64_t
+ int_least8_t, int_fast8_t, etc.
+ intmax_t, uintmax_t
+ intptr_t, uintptr_t
+ What are the exact-width types in <stdint.h>? intN_t / uintN_t - Exactly N bits wide. Optional (may not exist on some platforms).
int32_t x;   // exactly 32 bits
+ uint64_t y;  // exactly 64 bits
+ What are the minimum-width types in <stdint.h>? int_leastN_t / uint_leastN_t - At least N bits. Always available.
int_least32_t x;  // at least 32 bits
+ What are the fastest types in <stdint.h>? int_fastN_t / uint_fastN_t - Fastest type with at least N bits.
int_fast32_t x;  // fast, at least 32 bits
+ What are intptr_t and uintptr_t? Integer types capable of holding a pointer value. Optional.
void *p = ...;
+ intptr_t i = (intptr_t)p;
+ void *q = (void *)i;
+ What are intmax_t and uintmax_t? Maximum-width integer types. Can hold any value of any integer type.
intmax_t big = INTMAX_MAX;
+ What does <inttypes.h> provide? Format macros for <stdint.h> types and wide integer functions.
printf("%" PRId32 "\n", x);   // print int32_t
+ printf("%" PRIx64 "\n", y);   // print uint64_t as hex
+ imaxabs, imaxdiv
+ strtoimax, strtoumax
+ What are the PRIxN format macros? printf format specifiers for stdint.h types:
PRId8, PRId16, PRId32, PRId64   // signed decimal
+ PRIu8, PRIu16, PRIu32, PRIu64   // unsigned decimal
+ PRIx8, PRIx16, PRIx32, PRIx64   // hex
+ PRIo8, PRIo16, PRIo32, PRIo64   // octal
+ What are the SCNxN format macros? scanf format specifiers for stdint.h types:
SCNd32, SCNu64, SCNx16, etc.
+ int32_t x;
+ scanf("%" SCNd32, &x);
+ What does <complex.h> provide? Complex number support:
complex        // macro for _Complex
+ imaginary      // macro for _Imaginary (if available)
+ I              // imaginary unit
+ creal, cimag   // extract real/imaginary parts
+ cabs, carg     // magnitude, argument
+ conj           // conjugate
+ cexp, clog, cpow, csqrt
+ csin, ccos, ctan, etc.
+ How do you create a complex number in C99? 
#include <complex.h>
+ double complex z = 3.0 + 4.0*I;
+ double r = creal(z);  // 3.0
+ double i = cimag(z);  // 4.0
+ double m = cabs(z);   // 5.0
+ What does <tgmath.h> provide? Type-generic math macros. Calls appropriate function based on argument type.
#include <tgmath.h>
+ float f = 2.0f;
+ double d = 2.0;
+ sin(f);  // calls sinf
+ sin(d);  // calls sin

#if __STDC_VERSION__ >= 199901L

# === SECTION 2: New Keywords === What does the inline keyword do in C99? Hints to compiler that function calls should be expanded inline. Does not guarantee inlining.
inline int square(int x) {
    return x * x;
}
What are the inline semantics in C99? inline alone provides no external definition (for headers).
extern inline provides external definition.
// header: inline int f(int x) { return x*2; }
// one .c file: extern inline int f(int x);
What does the restrict keyword do in C99? Pointer qualifier promising no aliasing. Enables better optimization.
void copy(int *restrict dest,
          const int *restrict src, size_t n);
When should you use restrict? When pointers don't alias (point to overlapping memory). If they do alias and you use restrict, behavior is undefined. What is _Bool in C99? Boolean type that can hold 0 or 1. Any non-zero value converted to _Bool becomes 1.
_Bool flag = 42;  // flag = 1
What is _Complex in C99? Complex number types:
float _Complex
double _Complex
long double _Complex

Requires <complex.h> for operations. What is _Imaginary in C99? Imaginary-only types. Optional feature, rarely supported.
float _Imaginary
double _Imaginary

Check __STDC_IEC_559_COMPLEX__ for support. # === SECTION 3: New Headers === What does <stdbool.h> provide? Boolean macros:

What are the exact-width types in <stdint.h>? intN_t / uintN_t - Exactly N bits wide. Optional (may not exist on some platforms).
int32_t x;   // exactly 32 bits
uint64_t y;  // exactly 64 bits
What are the minimum-width types in <stdint.h>? int_leastN_t / uint_leastN_t - At least N bits. Always available.
int_least32_t x;  // at least 32 bits
What are the fastest types in <stdint.h>? int_fastN_t / uint_fastN_t - Fastest type with at least N bits.
int_fast32_t x;  // fast, at least 32 bits
What are intptr_t and uintptr_t? Integer types capable of holding a pointer value. Optional.
void *p = ...;
intptr_t i = (intptr_t)p;
void *q = (void *)i;
What are intmax_t and uintmax_t? Maximum-width integer types. Can hold any value of any integer type.
intmax_t big = INTMAX_MAX;
What does <inttypes.h> provide? Format macros for <stdint.h> types and wide integer functions.
printf("%" PRId32 "\n", x);   // print int32_t
printf("%" PRIx64 "\n", y);   // print uint64_t as hex

strtoimax, strtoumax
What are the PRIxN format macros? printf format specifiers for stdint.h types:
PRId8, PRId16, PRId32, PRId64   // signed decimal
PRIu8, PRIu16, PRIu32, PRIu64   // unsigned decimal
PRIx8, PRIx16, PRIx32, PRIx64   // hex
PRIo8, PRIo16, PRIo32, PRIo64   // octal
What are the SCNxN format macros? scanf format specifiers for stdint.h types:
SCNd32, SCNu64, SCNx16, etc.
int32_t x;
scanf("%" SCNd32, &x);
What does <complex.h> provide? Complex number support:
complex        // macro for _Complex
imaginary      // macro for _Imaginary (if available)
I              // imaginary unit
creal, cimag   // extract real/imaginary parts
cabs, carg     // magnitude, argument
conj           // conjugate
cexp, clog, cpow, csqrt
csin, ccos, ctan, etc.
How do you create a complex number in C99? 
#include <complex.h>
double complex z = 3.0 + 4.0*I;
double r = creal(z);  // 3.0
double i = cimag(z);  // 4.0
double m = cabs(z);   // 5.0
What does <tgmath.h> provide? Type-generic math macros. Calls appropriate function based on argument type.
#include <tgmath.h>
float f = 2.0f;
double d = 2.0;
sin(f);  // calls sinf
sin(d);  // calls sin
sin(z);  // calls csin (complex)

# === SECTION 4: Variable Length Arrays (VLAs) === What is a VLA in C99? Variable Length Array - Array whose size is determined at runtime.

// Parameter is restrict-qualified pointer to n ints
// Equivalent to: int *restrict arr
What is the static keyword in array parameters? Guarantees minimum array size to enable optimization.
void f(int arr[static 10]);
// Caller must provide at least 10 elements
// Enables optimizer to assume arr != NULL
What did C99 change about implicit int? Removed. Functions must have explicit return type. "Implicit int" was allowed in C89.
// C89 OK, C99 error:
main() { return 0; }
// C99 requires:
int main(void) { return 0; }
What did C99 change about implicit function declarations? Removed. Calling undeclared function is constraint violation in C99 (was allowed in C89 assuming int return). What is the idiv specification in C99? Truncation toward zero. In C89, integer division direction was implementation-defined for negative operands.
-7 / 2 = -3  // C99 guarantees this
-7 % 2 = -1  // remainder has sign of dividend
What is universal character names in C99? Unicode escapes in identifiers and strings.
\uXXXX   // 4 hex digits (BMP)
\UXXXXXXXX // 8 hex digits (full Unicode)

int caf\u00E9 = 1;  // identifier with e
What is the empty macro argument feature? C99 allows empty arguments to macros.
#define FOO(a, b) a ## b
FOO(x, )   // expands to: x
What is #pragma STDC? Standard pragmas for floating-point control:
#pragma STDC FENV_ACCESS ON
#pragma STDC FP_CONTRACT OFF
#pragma STDC CX_LIMITED_RANGE ON
"}
